replies.msg:
There surely are competitive classmates but they are few in number; in my years we have AOs, bankers, and doctors around and as you can imagine they are well tuned for examinations but most of my classmates are not aiming at PCLL-entering grades: but that’s just space so I can’t speak for speed classmates.

Re admissions
Less than a few per year from my knowledge. There are examples of first class grads who failed to secure PCLL admission until the second year after grad.

Re Study group
Not that many to my knowledge. The very significant learner diversity means that you don’t really get to form meaningful study groups without sheer luck.

The other problem with UOL LLB is they you don’t get career advice and internships as you may get from the “real” law schools

replies.msg:
Readings: yes. Tons of them (about 5k pages in my experience) if you want to achieve first. If you just want a 2:1 then the reading amount can go down to about 1k pages/subject

Space does offer notes. Quality depends a lot on the professor. You can refer to the three medium articles I wrote “how to study law” which has also been adopted by the UOL to the undergraduate blog.

replies.msg:
Agreed. MMU CPE is a more realistic option.

I had taken London U year 1 exam, but quickly changed to MMU CPE in view of the difficulty of enrollment into PCLL. Since then everything appears much easier, and really, if u make reasonable effort, it is not really difficult to get into PCLL. I guess I studied less than 20 hours per week for my law degree...

Generally speaking, u would get a chance to admit into PCLL if u have obtained high 2.1 around (little more than +65 core). Some classmates repeatedly applied for PCLL (for four years) and finally get admitted.

In my part time PCLL class, I can recall only two classmates from London U, but we have 30+ MMU classmates. The chance is more than ten times higher.

London U is a prestigious qualification, but if u want to pursue legal career, u have to make a choice.

I feel fortunate I made such a good move, now I am a trainee in a law firm.

If you had an average of 55 and wish to qualify the best bet would be to do another degree of law given your experience learnt here and put your current course to a stop. It sounds cruel but at the same time I wish to let you know this is the reality.

Good luck.

Agreed. MMU CPE is a more realistic option.

I had taken London U year 1 exam, but quickly changed to MMU CPE in view of the difficulty of enrollment into PCLL. Since then everything appears much easier, and really, if u make reasonable effort, it is not really difficult to get into PCLL. I guess I studied less than 20 hours per week for my law degree...

Generally speaking, u would get a chance to admit into PCLL if u have obtained high 2.1 around (little more than +65 core). Some classmates repeatedly applied for PCLL (for four years) and finally get admitted.

In my part time PCLL class, I can recall only two classmates from London U, but we have 30+ MMU classmates. The chance is more than ten times higher.

London U is a prestigious qualification, but if u want to pursue legal career, u have to make a choice.

I feel fortunate I made such a good move, now I am a trainee in a law firm.
